subsc: Sub-national government administration,Primary education,Tertiary education,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Lessons emphasize that
            working with state, and municipal governments (as these were
            directly responsible of the delivery of basic education), a
            recognition taken into account early on during project
            design, and implementation, ensured the political support,
            and demonstrated the efficacy of grassroots policies.
            Similarly, empowering schools through direct interventions,
            designed to generate greater school commitment to the
            project's development objectives, was conducive to
            success. This was demonstrated by an initial evaluation of
            the School Development Plan, which concluded that students
            under this plan performed better on assessment tests, and
            other dependent variables, such as student promotion rates.
            The popularity of these new educational development plans,
            presented the dilemma of expanding the project's
            success, though the project had reached its full training,
            and financial resources to bear. In response to this, the
            follow-up operation addresses expansion, with more explicit
            procedures, and criteria. The long-term strategy of an
            educational program (the project was prepared on previous
            project experiences, while lessons from this project will be
            incorporated to follow-up operations) allows for capacity
            building, technical skills, and innovations to flourish, and
            be institutionalized.
